item.description:
Uber monitors drivers to see when they're speeding. Brain-flown shark blimp. A paper on side-channel attacks with a brain-computer interface. Mindless computing.

OpenBCI videos. 4 people control giant shark blimp with BCI. Interesting that the word "biosensing" is used here.

On the feasability of side-channel attacks with brain-computer interfaces. Ivan Martinovic et al. USENIX '12. Dawn Song was on this paper.

We use inexpensive electroencephalography (EEG) based BCI devices to test the feasibility of simple, yet effective, attacks. The captured EEG signal could reveal the user’s private information about, e.g., bank cards, PIN numbers, area of living, the knowledge of the known persons [..] We show that the entropy of the private information is decreased on the average by approximately 15 % - 40 % compared to random guessing attacks.

Public Bits, A Knight News Challenge awardee.

An application that lets you search and download across data portals and sources, notifies you when your copy is out of date, and seeds the data as a public service to new downloaders.

Mindless computing: designing technologies to subtly influence behavior. The authors don't seem to mention how obviously terrifying this sounds.

Cardiogr.am. An app for Apple Watch + Android Wear.

Your heart beats 102,000 times per day, and it reacts to everything that happens in your life—what you're eating, how you exercise, a stressful moment, or a happy memory. What's your heart telling you?

what indeed.....

Uber has started monitoring smartphones to see when drivers are speeding. A quote from Uber CSO Joe Sullivan:

Gyrometers in phones can measure small movements, while GPS and accelerometers show how often a vehicle starts and stops, as well as its overall speed. If a rider complains that a driver accelerated too fast and broke too hard, we can review that trip using data. If the feedback is accurate, then we can get in touch with the driver. And if it’s not, we could use the information to make sure a driver’s rating isn’t affected.

DARPA announces grant on BCI research. Fitbit captures breakup. Kyoto senses heartrate from a distance.

Catching heartbeats with millimeter-wave radar. sensing heartrate without sensors on the body. here's a funny quote about how our pervasive sensing future will be "casual and relaxed":

"Heartbeats can now be measured without placing sensors on the human body, thanks to a new technology developed in Japan. 'Taking measurements with sensors on the body can be stressful and troublesome, because you have to stop what you're doing,' says Hiroyuki Sakai, a researcher at Panasonic. 'What we tried to make was something that would offer people a way to monitor their body in a casual and relaxed environment.'"

DARPA - Bridging the bio-electric divide. DARPA in the biosensing game with a $60m brain-computer interface grant.

Fitbit captures exact moment of devestating heartbreak. an interesting case, this guy made the personal decision to disclose of disclosure and made the decision to share this data, along with his captioning.

Breakup, as captured by my fitbit. #breakup #Fitbit pic.twitter.com/S9sLV2TlCC

— Koby (@iamkoby) January 19, 2016

Sensors that dissolve in the brain. from the same lab that brought us biosensing tattoos.

How to search the internet of things for pictures of sleeping babies. shodan search engine serves as a creepy reminder of why we need IoT security
